data.title: EffectParameter Additions / Completion
data.body:
I have added some changes to the `GetValue` methods to bring them up to the features of XNA. I also added a series of unit tests to ensure that I didn't break anything else.

Mostly, the current methods just catered for a single case, such as `GetValueMatrix`, which always failed if the data wasn't a 4x4 matrix. Now it supports a scalar, 2x3, 3x2, 3x4,4x3 and 4x4. (the 2x2,1x2, 2x1 seem to be missing from the other methods, so I didn't add them, but the can be)

A breaking change to the existing methods is the inclusion of a `int count` parameter to some of the `GetValueArray` methods. This is what XNA does and is a very useful feature. This size controls the size of the resulting array. For some reason, only some of these methods had the count parameter, such as `GetValueMatrixArray`.  
The breaking methods are:
- `GetValueSingleArray`
- `GetValueVector2Array`
- `GetValueVector3Array`
- `GetValueVector4Array`

These changes are the other side of #4268, I didn't touch those methods so that there will be no conflicts when merging.

NOTE: I made a whoopee somewhere and ended up with two PRs :( [#4299] Closed that one.

data.title: MediaPlayer.SetChannelVolume may fail despite null check (WinDX)
data.body:
Hello,

Despite [the null check](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/083d88ce8385cf6a454a372e1d5bbafbe83243cb/MonoGame.Framework/Media/MediaPlayer.WMS.cs#L150), it may happen that `MediaPlayer.SetChannelVolumes()` raise an exception because of the async nature of Media Foundation (Windows DirectX projects).

Two different (but related to the same problem) exceptions can occur.

1) [On this line](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/083d88ce8385cf6a454a372e1d5bbafbe83243cb/MonoGame.Framework/Media/MediaPlayer.WMS.cs#L154)

```
SharpDX.SharpDXException
 at SharpDX.Result.CheckError()
 at SharpDX.MediaFoundation.AudioStreamVolume.GetChannelCount(Int32& dwCountRef)
 at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Media.MediaPlayer.SetChannelVolumes()
```

2) [On this line](https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/blob/083d88ce8385cf6a454a372e1d5bbafbe83243cb/MonoGame.Framework/Media/MediaPlayer.WMS.cs#L155) or the previous one

```
System.NullReferenceException
 at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Media.MediaPlayer.SetChannelVolumes()
```

Situation 1 happens when the `_volumeController` is not yet ready.
Situation 2 happens when the `_volumeController` gets reset past the null check (i.e. a new session started but didn't went through the whole initialization yet).
Both are related to the async nature of starting a new session.

This problem rarely occurs, over thousands of sessions, we had 4 of these crashes reported.

@MichaelDePiazzi May I have your thoughts on this one? Every async initializaiton should be fine, I'm quite puzzled.

data.title: Mouse input on MonoGame OpenTK with multiple windows
data.body:
The issue only occurs on OpenGL (DirectX works fine). 

Steps to reproduce:
- Start the game
- Create a second instance of the game in separate AppDomain (`AppDomain.ExecuteAssemblyByName` on the same MonoGame project/executable).
- Close the newly created instance
- Mouse clicks will no longer be registered on the open window (`Mouse.GetState().LeftButton` always returns `ButtonState.Released`).

I suspect this may be an upstream issue with OpenTK -- especially since AppDomains don't sandbox native objects. Any insights?

data.title: TextureImporter fails while importing .bmp files
data.body:
TextureImporter is raising a NullReferenceException on line 236, when trying to import bitmaps with less than 8 bits per pixel.
This is happening in the develop branch. In version 3.4 it worked perfectly.

The reason is that the code is hardcoded to transform files with 8, 16, 24, or 32 bits per pixel, but does nothing with smaller sizes.

I have a fix for this ready that seems to work, at least for monochrome and 4 bits .bmp files, but I want to have a look to the rest of the code and possibly simplify it

data.title: Media Foundation (Song playback on DirectX) not working on Vista
data.body:
Hello,

It appears that `Song` playback doesn't work on Windows Vista. We have several reports of this exception:

```
SharpDX.SharpDXException: HRESULT: [0xC00D36E3], Module: [Unknown], ApiCode: [Unknown/Unknown], Message: Unknown
 at SharpDX.Result.CheckError()
 at SharpDX.MediaFoundation.MediaFactory.Startup(Int32 version, Int32 dwFlags)
 at SharpDX.MediaFoundation.MediaManager.Startup(Boolean useLightVersion)
 at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Media.MediaManagerState.CheckStartup()
 at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Media.MediaPlayer.PlatformInitialize()
 at Microsoft.Xna.Framework.Media.MediaPlayer..cctor()
```

Since we can't debug on users' machines, I don't have a more precise stack trace with the native debug messages.

According to this [SharpDX discussion](http://sharpdx.org/forum/4-general/3278-mediafoundation-and-windows-vista), Windows Vista runs a different Media Foundation version and may require an update. However, after redirecting users to the mentioned update, nothing changes and most users report that the update won't even install.

At first I thought it was related to #4176 but I can confirm it isn't.

The problem seems very rare, given that Vista users are now very few. There are merely a couple referenced occurrences of that problem on the internet.

My best guess would be that the current version of SharpDX targets a Media Foundation version incompatible with Windows Vista.

This problem, added to #4176 and the recent difficulties to rework DirectX `Song` playback make me wonder if it would be interesting to switch to another API, at least for the Windows Desktop platform (the other Windows platforms are most probably not affected by Media Foundation dependencies).

data.title: Bounty: Update audio system not to drain CPU on Android
data.body:
The audio system stays active on Android devices and continues to drain battery when Monogame apps are in inactive in the background. This has been documented here:

http://community.monogame.net/t/mg-android-game-keeps-draining-battery-life-in-background/2664

and here:

Monogame Issue https://github.com/mono/MonoGame/issues/3899

We wanted to post a $1,000 USD bounty for the successful resolution of this issue and it's acceptance into the Monogame develop branch. It looks like there are two viable solutions, one is to compile a new openal-soft library and use the new functions to pause suspend/pause the device when necessary. Another would be a fully managed mixer. Either way, this is a big blocker for anyone pushing games to production on Android, and we hope for a final solution soon :)

data.title: [Mac] Upgrade Protobuild, Allow MacOS to target newer Xamarin APIs, etc.
data.body:
This PR addresses multiple issues at once because they're all dependent on one another:
- **Upgrades Protobuild:** Throughout the course of this PR I had to make changes to Protobuild to support the newer APIs and fix various issues across platforms, so that is updated here.
- **Remove old XSLTs:** With the Windows Universal and tvOS platforms upstreamed into Protobuild, there's no need for MonoGame to keep it's own copies of the XSLT files any more.  This PR removes them in favour of the built-in ones.  This will assist with #4218.
- **Mac now supports the Xamarin.Mac Unified API:** It supports both the MonoMac API, XamMac API and newer Xamarin.Mac API (unified).  The older APIs are supported by #ifdef'ing namespaces with the `PLATFORM_MACOS_LEGACY` define.  This resolves #4275, but should also fix bugs like #4278.
- **WindowsUAP is now WindowsUniversal:** This brings the MonoGame platform name inline with the platform name being used in upstream.  See https://github.com/hach-que/Protobuild/pull/130 for the name change reasoning.
